questions.text: A first-time mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  On microscopic examination, these papular lesions on an erythematous base will reveal ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of erythema neonatorum. Wright stained smear of the contents of the pustule will show an abundance of eosinophils.

They are papular lesions on an erythematous base, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. They are seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for up to a week, after which they resolve spontaneously.

Neutrophils are seen in pustular melanosis. 

 

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Ayesha is a 9th standard girl who presented with a neck swelling, which began more than a year ago. Her mother says she is embarrassed about it and always covers her neck with a shawl when she goes to school. Her menstrual cycles have also become irregular as of late. Blood tests reveal slightly elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPO-Abs) and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level in a child with a goitre is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis.

Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. Clinical presentation can include goitre, growth retardation, and other features of hypothyroidism. The thyroid is diffusely enlarged, firm, and non-tender.

TSH is moderately elevated and TPO-Abs and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-Tg Abs) can be detected.

The image given below shows goitre due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.text: A pregnant female arrives at your hospital for her antenatal check-up. As an intern, you were required to draw her family pedigree chart while taking history. She has previously delivered full-term healthy dizygotic twins 5 years back. Which of the following symbol will you use to denote dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Pedigree charts are graphical representations of a person's family tree and are useful for identifying the pattern of inheritance of genetic disorders. Thus, they are vital in the history-taking of patients, especially in pregnancy. Option B is the symbol denoting dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart.

Option A denotes monozygotic twins in the pedigree chart.
Option C denotes offsprings.
Option D denotes consanguineous marriage.

Related Pearl: Pedigree symbols

questions.text: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tract infection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury in this condition?
questions.solution:
The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial cell.

Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseases characterized by the deposition of immune complexes.

Mesangial cell diseases:

  • IgA nephropathy
  • IgM nephropathy
  • Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Class II lupus nephritis
  • Diabetic nephropathy

Note: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks is observed in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: You are assisting on a left partial nephrectomy in a child with Wilms tumor. Intraoperatively, a small mass is noted on the right kidney as well. Frozen section reveals it to be a Wilms tumor. What is the stage of Wilm's tumor in this child?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor with involvement of both kidneys is stage 5.

Children’s Oncology Group (COG) Staging System

Stage I

Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.

Stage II

Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.

Stage III

Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor.

Stage IV

Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)

or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region

Stage V

Metastasis to opposite kidney (bilateral renal involvement)

questions.text: Reena, a 34-year-old lady with gestation diabetes mellitus delivers an LGA baby at 37 weeks. What would the birth weight of this child be?
questions.solution:
Infants with birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for their gestational age are called large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

Maternal diabetes and obesity are predisposing factors for LGA babies. They have a higher incidence of: 

  • Birth injuries:  
    • Brachial plexus injury
    • Phrenic nerve injury
    • Cephalohematomas
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Congenital heart disease

questions.text: You are asked to review an article titled, 'Childhood cancers- a menace'. Which of the following statements is wrong and needs to be edited out?

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children with Down syndrome.
The most common intra-abdominal malignancy is Wilm’s tumor.
The most common extracranial solid malignancy is neuroblastoma.
The most common brain tumors in children are infratentorial.

questions.solution:
The most common intraabdominal malignancy in children is neuroblastoma. 

  • The most common leukemias seen in Down’s syndrome: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) > acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
  • The most common site of a brain tumor in children: Infratentorium
  • The most common extra-cranial solid neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common intra-abdominal neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common primary neoplasm of renal tissue in children: Wilm’s tumor

questions.text: Anwesha, an orator preparing for her international debate finale presents to your clinic with lesions on her lower lip as shown below. She is concerned as these lesions are painful, recurrent and hamper the flow of her speech. Which of the following points about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: They are seen in Gluten-sensitive enteropathy

questions.solution:
The lesions given in the above image are aphthous ulcers, and they are not contagious. All the other points are true. 

Aphthous ulcers are painful, recurrent, and non-contagious oral lesions. They are well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesions with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo. They heal in 10–14 days without scarring. Their aetiology is unclear but the following factors have been implicated:

    1. Allergic or immunologic reactions
    2. Emotional stress
    3. Genetics
    4. Injury to soft tissues in the mouth
    5. Inflammatory bowel disease
    6. Gluten-sensitive enteropathy
    7. Behcet disease
    8. Sweet syndrome
    9. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
    10. Cyclical neutropenia

Treatment generally includes local anaesthetic to relieve pain and B-complex supplementation to enhance healing.

questions.text: An anxious new mother feeding her child with expressed breastmilk (EBM) feels that the consistency and colour of her milk have changed recently. She adds that when she expresses breastmilk, the colour and consistency of the first portion and the ending portion is completely different and that she is worried about the same.  Which statement is not true about different breast milk?

choices.text: Mature milk is thicker with all the essential nutrients for growth
Foremilk is watery and is rich in proteins and sugar
Hindmilk is richer in fat and provides more energy

questions.solution:
Mature milk is thinner (not thicker) with all essential nutrients for growth.

Various transitional forms of breastmilk:

Colostrum

  • In the initial 3 to 4 days
  • Small quantity, thick, and yellow in colour
  • A large number of antibodies, immune component cells; and vitamins A, D, E, and K.

Transitional milk

  • Secreted after 3 to 4 days until 2 weeks
  • Immunoglobulin and protein content decreases, while the fat and sugar content increases.

Mature milk

  • Follows transitional milk.
  • Thinner and more watery.
  • Contains all the nutrients essential for the optimal growth of the baby. 

Foremilk

  • Secreted at the start of the feed
  • Watery and rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water that quenches the baby’s thirst.

Hindmilk 

  • Comes towards the end of the feed
  • Provides more energy and a sense of satiety and it is richer in fat.

Preterm milk 

  • Milk of mother who delivers before 37 weeks.
  • Contains more proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobins, and calories as per the requirement of the preterm infant.

The given image shows watery foremilk and hindmilk which is rich in fat.

questions.text: You are reading an article titled, ' Dark age vampires or our patients', which describes an 18-year-old man who has had an intolerance to sunshine since the age of 6. When playing cricket he suffered intense burning, redness, swelling, and crusting of knees unprotected by shorts, with similar changes on cheeks and bridge of the nose. His labs showed elevated concentrations of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies can explain this boy's condition?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of cutaneous photosensitivity beginning in childhood and a substantially elevated concentration of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin supports a diagnosis of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic protoporphyria is ferrochelatase (FECH).

Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposure and followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resemble angioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer. Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nail changes, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual.

Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyte and plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormal liver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.

Afamelanotide, a synthetic analogue of the alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone is recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The drug acts by increasing sunlight tolerance.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinic with a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have Graves’ disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of the following except __________.
questions.solution:
Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease.

Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases): 

  • Diabetes mellitus type 1
  • Pernicious anaemia
  • Celiac disease
  • Vitiligo
  • Addison disease
  • Alopecia areata
  • Myasthenia gravis

questions.text:
A child with CAH having cortisol deficiency is treated with glucocorticoids. How should the dose of glucocorticoids be altered during an inter-current infection?

CAH - Congenital Adrenal hyperplasia

choices.text: Dose should be tapered and stopped
Dose should be doubled or tripled
Glucocorticoids should be withdrawn until the infection resolves

questions.solution:
Cortisol deficiency in CAH is treated with glucocorticoids.

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as an infection or surgery. This is because, during periods of stress, the requirement for cortisol is higher.

questions.text: Gelastic seizures are associated with
questions.solution:
Gelastic seizures are characteristically associated with hypothalamic hamartoma.

Gelastic seizures :

  • Epileptic events characterised by bouts of laughter.
  • Autonomic features are present.
  • Hypothalamic hamartomas present with triad of :
    • Gelastic epilepsy
    • Precocious puberty
    • Developmental delay

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with features of hypotonia. On examination , he has tongue fasciculations, normal intelligence , keeps his body in a frog like position. The most likely diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Floppy Infant syndrome.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness.

Among the causes of Floppy Infant syndrome, Spinal muscular atrophy is the best choice as:

  • Intelligence is normal
  • Tongue fasciculations

Other options :

  • Down’s syndrtome – Intelligence impaired
  • Guillian barre – Acute condition with history of fever or viral infections.

questions.text: All of the following are used in diagnosis of HIV in a 2 month old child except
questions.solution:
HIV ELISA cannot be used in diagnosis of HIV in a child upto 18 months of age.

  • This is because all neonates born to HIV infected mothers will have IgG antibody in their blood regardless of their infection status.
  • So up until 18 months of age they will continue to test positive. Hence HIV ELISA should not be used.

questions.text: Sandifer syndrome due to GERD in infants is most often confused with ?
questions.solution:
• Abnormal or Dystonic neck posturing in Sandifer syndrome is most often confused with Seizures.
  • Posturing in Sandifer syndrome occurs 1 hour after feeding, and babies frequently have a history of vomiting, failure to thrive and repeated chest infections.

questions.text: Test done  to diagnose syphilis in newborn if mother is syphilitic is
questions.solution: Syphilis captia M test is an Enzyme immunoassay used to detect syphilis in newborn if the mother is syphilitic.

questions.text: First sign of puberty in a female is
questions.solution:
Thelarche is the first sign of puberty in girls.

  • Beginning of secondary breast development at onset of puberty
  • Tanner stage 2
  • Due to increased levels of Estradiol

questions.text: Automatism is seen in all except
questions.solution:
• Infantile spasm doesn't present with automatism
  • Automatism are the characteristic feature of Complex partial seizures.
  • Automatisms are automatic semi purposeful movements of mouth (oral,alimentary such as chewing) or of the extremities (eg.manipulation of sheets/walking).

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). 

CP is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait. Flaccid paralysis would be seen in lower motor neuron disease. 

Other options:

Option A: Hypotonia is a characteristic feature of athetoid CP. These infants generally have poor head control. 

Option B: Microcephaly can be seen in CP due to perinatal insults to the developing brain. 

Option C: Ataxia is a common feature of extrapyramidal CP.

questions.text: In a child with Tetralogy of Fallot, with fever and diarrhoea, which is the surest sign of a cyanotic spell?
questions.solution:
The absence of murmur can be considered as a sure sign of Cyanotic spell.

There is a characteristic temporary decrease or absence of systolic murmur during a cyanotic spell because of decreased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with an upper limb deformity as given in the image below. He has had recurrent respiratory infections and is breathless while walking. You hear a wide split and fixed second heart sound through all phases of respiration. Identify the heart disease likely to be present in this child.
questions.solution:
The heart disease likely to be present in this child is an atrial septal defect (ASD).

The given clinical history along with the image is suggestive of Holt Oram syndrome. The syndrome is characterized by hypoplasia of the thumb, phocomelia, atrial septal defect, and triphalangism. 

Clinical features of ASD include exercise intolerance and failure to thrive although many children are asymptomatic. On auscultation, there is a widely split and fixed second heart sound in all phases of respiration, along with an ejection systolic murmur. Occasionally an ejection click is heard over the pulmonary area.

Chest X-ray shows enlarged right atrium and right ventricle. The diagnosis can be further affirmed in ECG which interprets right ventricular volume overload with normal peripheral vascular resistance. The location and size of the ASD can be confirmed in 2D scanning of the defect. Treatment involves closure of the defect either by surgery or by percutaneous catheter device insertion over the defect. 

Other options:

Option B: Transposition of great vessels (TGV) - ejection systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2 with features of cyanosis and failure to thrive.

Option C: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) - continuous murmur is distinctly heard on auscultation due to systolic and diastolic overloading of the pulmonary artery. 

Option D Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) - pulmonary ejection systolic murmur with a tricuspid flow murmur.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for a primary grade 5 VUR involving both kidneys in a 6 month old boy is

choices.text: Cystoscopy followed by subureteric injection of Teflon

questions.solution:
Treatment of choice of Grade 5 Vesico Ureteric Reflux :

  • Less than 1 year – Antibiotic prophylaxis
  • 1-5 years – Unilateral - Antibiotic prophylaxis
  • 1-5 years – Bilateral – Surgery
  • 1-5 years with scarring – Surgery
  • Above 5 years – Surgery

questions.text: A newborn is being evaluated for anuria. Imaging reveals renal agenesis and pulmonary hypoplasia. The delivery was complicated due to oligohydramnios. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history of oligohydramnios, is suggestive of Potter's sequence

Potter's sequence is characterized by the triad of:

  • Renal agenesis
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia

Option B: Pierre–Robin syndrome: micrognathia, retrognathia, glossoptosis.

Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: It can present with pulmonary hypoplasia but other features like renal agenesis, anuria will not be seen.

Option D: CHARGE syndrome: Coloboma of the eye, Heart anomaly, choanal Atresia, Retardation, Genital and Ear anomalies.

questions.text: A male infant born at 34 weeks of gestation by emergency LSCS was found to have the following finding on histopathological examination of his umbilical cord. Anomalies of which of the following systems are most likely to be found in this infant?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a  single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased risk for an occult renal anomaly.

The histopathological image of the cross-section of the umbilical cord shows 2 vessels as marked, a thin-walled umbilical vein and a thicker-walled umbilical artery. 

 

The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries.

Trisomy 18 is a common association.

questions.text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby, totally occupied with his little game and a mother trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.solution:
A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months.

A child makes a tower of:

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years

questions.text: A 4-year old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection is erythema infectiosum, also known as the fifth disease, which is a benign, self-limited exanthematous illness of childhood. Affected children are afebrile or have a mild fever and do not appear ill. ( as in this child)

  • The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which occurs in 3 stages
    • The initial stage is erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance
    • The rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema in the 2nd stage
    • Central clearing of macular lesions occurs promptly, giving the rash a lacy, reticulated appearance
  • The rash tends to be more prominent on extensor surfaces, sparing the palms and soles.

 

B19 and HBoV (human bocavirus) are the only 2 parvoviruses known to be pathogenic in humans.

 

Other options:

Fever is characteristically high with Scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease (unlike in this patient)

The malar rash which is pathognomonic of SLE involves the cheek, bridge of nose and lower eyelids; Discoid lesions are rare in childhood; photosensitivity rash may be present

questions.text: In phenylketonuria, the following phenylketones are excreted in urine:
questions.solution:
• In phenylketonuria (PKU), excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenylketones – phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate; that are excreted in urine, giving rise to the term phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • Acetoacetate and beta hydroxybutyrate are keto acids but are not phenylketones.

questions.text: An infant comes to a paediatrician and on examination there is a coarse systolic murmur in the mitral area with mild exercise intolerance. On echocardiogram there is a small muscular VSD. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch till 2 years then operate
Restrict physical activity and operate when weight is more than 15 kgs
Reassure about the benign nature of the disease and advice about dental hygiene

questions.solution:
Reassure the parents about the benign nature of the disease and the dental hygiene to be carefully maintained as they are at high risk for infective endocarditis.

  • In patients with small VSDs
    • Parents should be reassured of the benign nature of the lesion
    • They should be encouraged to live a normal life
    • No restrictions on physical activity
    • Surgical repair is not recommended
  • Small muscular VSDs are more likely to close (up to 80%) than membranous VSDs (up to 35%)
  • They only have a long-term risk for infective endocarditis so as a protection against infective endocarditis, the integrity of primary and permanent teeth should be carefully maintained.
  • The latest revision of the American Heart Association guidelines states: 
    • Antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended for dental visits or surgical procedures.
    • Patients can be monitored by a combination of clinical examination and non-invasive laboratory tests until the VSD has closed spontaneously.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?
questions.solution:
Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure

After birth:

  • The pulmonary vascular resistance decreases
  • The aortic pressure increases due to increased venous return from the lungs.
  • The blood flow through the ductus reverses
  • Highly oxygenated blood flows from the aorta through the ductus which creates a stimulus for the muscular spasm and subsequent closure.
  • Thus, in a full-term neonate, oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.
  • When the Po2 of the blood passing through the ductus reaches about 50 mm Hg, the ductal wall begins to constrict.
  • The effects of oxygen on ductal smooth muscle may be direct or mediated by its effects on prostaglandin synthesis.
  • Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed.

questions.text: Trans fats should account for ____ % of total daily energy in children
questions.solution:
The current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents recommend that:

  • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy
  • Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy
  • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day
  • No trans-fat

questions.text: A 2 week old baby suspected to have congenital adrenal hyperplasia; the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (21-hydroxylase deficiency) is most reliably established by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone.
  • Measurements are taken before and 30 or 60 min after an intravenous bolus of 0.125-0.25 mg of cosyntropin (ACTH 1-24).
  • Nomograms exist that readily distinguish normal and patients with non-classic and classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.text: Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia is caused by deficiency of
questions.solution:
Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia type 2) is caused by deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase.

Disease Enzyme deficient

Tyrosinemia type 2 (Oculocutaneous) Tyrosine aminotransferase
Tyrosinemia type 3 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase [4-HPPD]
Hawkinsinuria Missense mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD

questions.text: A preterm, extremely low birth weight baby, delivered by emergency caesarian section was admitted to the NICU and treated for respiratory distress syndrome. She responded to treatment and was discharged. At 6 months of age, she is still having recurrent respiratory distress and requires supplemental oxygen at home. The baby was diagnosed with bronchopulmonary dysplasia. Which of the following does not cause this clinical complication?
questions.solution:
Inhalation of nitrous oxide (N2O) is not associated with bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). Inhaled NO is a pulmonary vasodilator approved for the treatment of hypoxic respiratory failure in term and near-term infants with pulmonary hypertension. It may have a role in preventing BPD.

BPD is a pathologic process leading to clinical features of chronic lung disease that originates in the neonatal period and is defined by an oxygen requirement for 28 days postnatally. Inflammatory injury to the developing lungs due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity resulting from prolonged mechanical ventilation is the key factor driving the pathogenesis of BPD. Together with other antenatal and postnatal factors, it results in aberrant tissue repair, dysregulated vascular and arrested alveolar development, which is the basis of the pathology seen in BPD.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of fever and rashes for the past 1 week after extensive workup gets diagnosed as Juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia. Which of the following findings is not consistent with this baby’s diagnosis?

choices.text: The genetic study may reveal NF-1 mutation
The presence of Philadelphia chromosome on FISH
The bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern with <20% blasts.
The peripheral smear reveals nucleated RBCs

questions.solution:
Patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia do not have the Philadelphia chromosome.

Formerly termed juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), it is a clonal proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells that typically affects children younger than 2 years of age. Patients with JMML present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations.

Patients with this disease do not have the Philadelphia chromosome (the Philadelphia chromosome is characteristic of CML). The peripheral blood smear shows an elevated leukocyte count with increased monocytes, thrombocytopenia, and anemia with the presence of erythroblasts. Bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern, with blasts accounting for <20% of cells. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and Noonan syndrome have a predilection for this type of leukemia.

JMML in the setting of Noonan syndrome is unique, with most patients having a spontaneous resolution.

questions.text: False positive low APGAR score is seen in all except __________.
questions.solution:
False positive low APGAR score is seen in all of the above except Maternal acidosis.

Maternal acidosis is associated with fetal acidosis and a normal APGAR score i.e. False-negative APGAR.

False positive low Apgar scores i.e no fetal acidosis but low Apgar score is seen in:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs - analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulphate
  • Acute cerebral edema
  • Spinal cord trauma
  • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Choanal atresia
  • Congenital pneumonia and sepsis
  • Congenital myopathy/neuropathy
  • Hemorrhage / hypovolemia
  • Precipitous delivery

False-negative APGAR i.e. Normal Apgar score with fetal acidosis is seen in:

  • Maternal acidosis
  • High fetal catecholamine levels
  • Some full-term infants

questions.text: The most characteristic finding of HIV in children is _________
questions.solution:
• Failure to thrive is the universal characteristic finding in HIV children.
  • Most common AIDS-defining illness in children is P. carinii pneumonia.
  • Most common fungal infection of HIV children is oral candidiasis.
  • Most common GI disease is chronic or recurrent diarrhea with malabsorption.
  • Most common hematological manifestation is anemia.
  • Most common renal disease is nephrotic syndrome.
  • Most common neoplasms are non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma and leiomyosacomas.

questions.text: An 8-year-old  child is brought with complaints of pain in the neck and right shoulder with a restricted range of motion. He also experiences difficulty walking. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a child with pain in the neck and right shoulder with a restricted range of motion and difficulty in walking with the clinical image showing winging of the right scapula suggests a diagnosis of facioscapulohumeral dystrophy. 

Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder with weakness of facial and shoulder girdle muscles as the earliest and most severe manifestation. Facial weakness causes rounded and puckered lips and the inability to close eyes while sleeping. Scapular winging is a prominent feature even in infants. There is flattening of the deltoid contour and wasting of the triceps and biceps. There is gradual weakness of muscles of the hip girdle and thighs, which eventually undergo atrophy, leading to Gower's sign and Trendelenburg gait. Lumbar lordosis and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.

Other options:

Option B- Long thoracic nerve palsy can cause scapular winging, most- commonly medial winging, due to traumatic injuries and nontraumatic events due to dysfunction of the serratus anterior.

Option C- Klippel Feil syndrome consists of a triad of low posterior hairline, short neck and decreased cervical range of motion.

Option D-Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels as well as the lateral corticospinal tracts and the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: A patient of VSD with CCF develops clubbing with no cyanosis. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
VSD is the commonest congenital lesion complicated by infective endocarditis. This patient with CCF and clubbing is exhibiting clinical features correlating to endocarditis

  • Some features of infective endocarditis indicating the involvement of the cardiovascular system include appearance of right or left heart failure (as seen in this patient) or development of a new murmur.
  • Features of immunological response include clubbing (as seen in this patient), myalgia, splenomegaly and microscopic hematuria.
  • Clubbing and splenomegaly tend to appear 3 weeks after the onset of endocarditis.

Other options:

  • Right to left shunt would give rise to Cyanosis (which is absent in this patient).
  • Large left to right shunts can develop CCF as a complication but they will not have clubbing (as seen in this patient).
  • Pulmonary edema is unlikely to cause clubbing.

questions.text: Anika, a 6-year-old girl good at sprint events, has been avoiding her track practices over the recent few weeks. Her mother informs that she skips her classes owing to her knee pain. Her X-ray reveals subperiosteal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pseudoparalysis which is a feature of scurvy - vitamin C deficiency

The subperiosteal haemorrhages in the lower limb bones can cause acute swelling and pain; the condition might mimic acute osteomyelitis or arthritis. The child refuses to walk because of the pain; hence, it is called pseudoparalysis.

questions.text: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes _____________
questions.solution:
Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria.

Other options:

  • Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD)
  • Variegate porphyria: Deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX)
  •  X-Linked protoporphyria: Gain of function mutation of δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS2)

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is rushed to the emergency department because of an episode of fits associated with uprolling of eyes and high fever. Kernig’s sign is negative and there are no post-ictal neurological deficits. There is a history of a similar episode when the child had a fever due to gastroenteritis. Which of the following is false regarding this type of seizures?

choices.text: Likelihood of developing epilepsy is low
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions
Absence of having a developmental delay

questions.solution:
This is a probable case of febrile seizures due to the presence of high fever, no post-ictal deficits and a negative Kernig's sign ruling out meningitis. Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure, as the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly.

Febrile seizures are seizures that-

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails or in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

questions.text: A child comes with cyanotic spells and chest Xray was as shown below; What is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum

questions.solution:
The typical radiologic configuration as shown in the anteroposterior view above is that of TOF and consists of:

  • A narrow base.
  • Concavity of the left heart border in the area usually occupied by the pulmonary artery.
  • Normal overall heart size.
  • The hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal and pointing horizontally to the left chest wall. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot (“coeur en sabot”).
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

questions.text: Following a term Caesarean delivery, a newborn presents with fast breathing. On examination, respiratory rate is 68/min and the chest is clear. A chest X-ray shows fluid in the intralobar fissures and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most prominent diagnosis in a newborn with tachypnea, clear chest, and given X-ray findings of intralobar fluid and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings is transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN).

TTN is a self-limited cause of tachypnea associated with delayed absorption of fetal lung fluid. It is characterized by early-onset tachypnea that is relieved by minimal oxygen supplementation (<40%). There maybe retractions, expiratory grunting, or cyanosis which also resolves with oxygen. On examination, the chest is clear without crackles or wheeze.

The chest X-ray shows prominent pulmonary vascular markings, fluid in the intralobar fissures, and, rarely, small pleural effusions.

Most infants recover usually within 3 days with supportive care.

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease- Radiographic findings like hypoaeration, diffuse reticulo-granular pattern, and air bronchograms will be seen.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in term or post-term infants. The infants are meconium-stained and may be depressed and require resuscitation at birth; The typical chest radiograph is characterized by patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of both lung fields, and hyperinflation.

Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia presents with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds heard in the chest wall.

questions.text: As a part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, you screen preschool children for anemia. What Hb values would prompt you to diagnose anemia in this age group?
questions.solution:
Anaemia in a preschool child is defined as a hemoglobin level of <11 g/dL.

Preschool age is defined as 2 to 5 years.

WHO cut-offs for the diagnosis of anaemia:

Age Hemoglobin (g/dL)
6 months to 5years <11 
5 to 11 years <11.5
12 to 14 years <12
Non-pregnant women (≥15 years) <12
Pregnant women <11
Men (≥15 years) <13

questions.text: You are evaluating JIA patients in a pediatric rheumatology clinic. As per the ILAR criteria, which of the following patients would you not include under JIA?

choices.text: A 18-year-old with RF negative Polyarthritis first diagnosed 3 years back

questions.solution:
Reactive arthritis is not a subtype of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis(JIA) so you would not include this subset of patients under your evaluation.

ILAR (International League of Associations for Rheumatology) defines JIA as arthritis of one or more joints with onset below 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks.

The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):-

  1. Oligoarthritis (4 or lesser joints) (Most common type)
  2. Polyarthritis (5 or more joints)
    1. RF Positive
    2. RF Negative
  3. Systemic JIA
  4. Psoriatic arthritis
  5. Enthesitis-related arthritis
  6. Undifferentiated

questions.text: A small baby who was being evaluated for multiple bone fractures with minor trauma is found to have brittle bone disease. Which of the following is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is caused by defects in type 2 collagen.
Blue sclerae and deafness may be associated.
Biphosphonates are useful in the treatment.

questions.solution:
Brittle bone disease is another name for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It is due to defects in type 1 collagen, not type 2 collagen.

There are 12 types of OI, with type 1 being the most common. Triad of fragile bones, blue sclera, and deafness is known as van der Hoeve syndrome. Treatment includes bisphosphonate therapy and orthopedic rehabilitation.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: A neonate with trisomy 21 has anemia, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, and no life-threatening complications on examination.CBC reveals high leucocyte count and peripheral smear shows numerous myeloblasts. The genetic makeup of blast cells when studied reveals GATA-1 mutations. At 3 months of age, his CBC counts come back to normal and there are no blast cells in his peripheral smear. As his treating physician, what would you recommend?
questions.solution:
This infant has a transient myeloproliferative disease, which usually resolves spontaneously in the first 3 months of life, and they require close-follow up because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life.

Approximately 10% of neonates with Down syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder characterized by high leukocyte counts, blast cells in the peripheral blood, and associated anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. Although these neonates can require temporary transfusion support, they do not require chemotherapy unless there is evidence of life-threatening complications.

As only 20-30% of such children develop acute megakaryocytic leukemia a bone marrow transplant would be a drastic step in our case.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal distension, fatigue, and night sweats for the past 4 months. He also has a 2-month history of postprandial fullness and recurrent non-bilious vomiting. On examination, he is pale, has hepatosplenomegaly and shifting dullness. A CT scan shows mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement. A biopsy specimen of the mesenteric lymph node reveals tumor cells with high mitotic index and starry sky pattern. The cytogenetic study revealed t(8;14).To stage the disease, which of the following systems would you use?
questions.solution:
Retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and short duration of disease, point towards a diagnosis of lymphoid neoplasms.The classic translocation of t(8;14) and starry sky appearance with a high mitotic index on HPE point toward a diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt’s lymphoma is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma worldwide. St Jude system of staging is used for staging childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Disease

System of staging

Hodgkin lymphoma

Ann–Arbor staging

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

St Jude(Murphy) staging

Chronic lymphoid leukemia

Rai staging
Binet staging

The current revised staging system used for NHL is the International Pediatric Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Staging System (IPNHLSS) which reflects our increasing ability to diagnose lower levels of organ involvement with disease. For instance, the older staging system (St. Jude/Murphy classification) did not account for molecular or flow cytometry involvement of bone marrow, which is now reflected in the new system.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, except ______

choices.text: Acidosis due to intestinal bacterial overgrowth

questions.solution:
Acidosis due to intestinal bacterial overgrowth causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis because of excessive bacterial metabolism of glucose into lactic acid.

Anion gap

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulphate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap.

Anion gap = [Na+] −([Cl-]+[HCO3-])

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic acidosis is of two types:

(1) Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

  • Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption)
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel)

(2) High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

  • Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy)
  • Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation)
  • Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

Methanol Fistula pancreatic
